data.text: Contents
Holding Children Still for a Particular Procedure .................................................... 6
Introduction
To promote best practice for the holding of children for clinical procedures.
Objectives
To ensure that all children cared for by Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust are held still using best practice.
Each child is listened to and their rights respected.
To maintain safety and protection of the child during clinical procedures.
To facilitate effective examination/ treatment of the child.
Definitions

table_items.text: This means immobilisation, which may be by splinting or by using limited force. It may be a method of helping children, with their permission, to manage a painful procedure quickly and effectively. Holding is distinguished from restraint by the degree of force required and the intention.
The Department of Health defines restraint as “the positive application of force with the intention of overpowering the child”. By definition restraint is applied without the child's consent.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Nursing and Quality for Children and Young People and paediatric wards' managers are responsible for ensuring paediatric staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Paediatric Clinical Lead Consultant is responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All paediatric staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
The Principles of good practice

An ethos of caring and respect for the child's rights, where the use of restrictive physical interventions or therapeutic holding without the child/ young person's consent are used as a last resort and are NOT first line interventions.
A consideration of the legal implications of using physical interventions needs to be made.

table_items.text: Children under 16 years old can give consent for themselves if they are judged to be
If a child under 16 years is judged competent and refuses treatment, this can be
overruled by a person with Parental Responsibility, if the doctors think that it is in their
best interests. However, if a child under 16 is judged competent and agrees to
treatment, this cannot be overruled by someone with Parental Responsibility.
If a child under 16 years is judged incapable of making the decision, either due to their
age, their emotional maturity or learning disabilities, then a person with Parental
Responsibility can give their permission. Parental Responsibility refers to the
individual who has legal rights, responsibilities, duties, power and authority to make
Young people aged 16 years or older, their ability to consent for themselves is
judged by the Mental Capacity Act 2005. Further information is available online
If they have capacity they can refuse.
If a child is aged 16 or 17 years old, the law states that they must be the person who
is asked to give consent unless they are not able to make the decision. A parent can
only give consent on behalf of a 16 or 17 year old child if they are legally unable to
consent for themselves. Parents cannot give consent for young people aged 18
years or over, even if they cannot consent for themselves. The only exception to this
is if you have applied successfully for an Order from the Court of Protection. (For
further information please refer to the 040801 Consent to Examination or Treatment

data.text: Openness about who decides what is in the best interests of the child/young person. Where possible the decisions need to be made with the full involvement of the parent or guardian.
A clear mechanism for staff to be heard if they disagree with a decision.
Sufficient staff who are competent and confident in safe and appropriate techniques for therapeutic holding
Hospital Play Specialists and Nursery Nurses available to provide preparation and on- going procedural distraction and play.
Holding a child still for a particular procedure requires:
Give careful consideration to whether the procedure is really necessary, and whether urgency in an emergency prohibits alternative techniques.

Anticipate and prevent the need for holding by giving information making use of the play specialists where available to prepare the child fully. Encourage the child and use effective distraction techniques.
Only if absolutely necessary sedation may be required. (Refer to appendix 1 for the sedation flowchart)
Obtain consent in all but the very youngest children (DOH 2009) and in all non emergency situations seek consent of parent/ carer or an independent advocate.
Agree with the child and parents/ guardians beforehand on the methods that will be used and for how long. Ensure this is fully documented.
Ensure parental presence and involvement if they wish. They should however not be made to feel guilty if they do not wish to participate.
Make use of minimum pressure and age appropriate techniques such as wrapping and splinting.
Consider the use of sucrose in babies prior to procedure (Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Analgesia in neonates; register number 09016)
Comfort the child and give a clear explanation of why holding still was necessary if the child has not been able to consent.

If staff, parents or the child/ young person feel undue forceful holding has occurred a report should be made using the DATIX system and all parties should be made aware of the complaints procedure should they wish to pursue that route.
Training requirements
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up to date in order to complete their portfolio and appraisal.
During induction all staff will receive instruction on current policies and guidelines and how to access them.
Staff will regularly receive updated guidelines to read.
Infection prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after procedures.
Monitoring and audit
Where a Patient's notes have demonstrated that the appropriate action has not been taken then a ‘DATIX' form is to be completed. This will highlight further staff training needs.
A quarterly DATIX audit will be examined by the Lead Nurse and the clinical director and risk lead for CYP.

Where a child's notes have demonstrated that the appropriate action has not been taken a ‘risk event form' is to be completed. This will address any further training needs for staff that require updating.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Paediatric Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.

It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform the Paediatric Practice Steering Group and appropriate Paediatric Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
This Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of individuals. (Refer to appendix 2)
References
RCN (2003) Restraining, holding still and containing children: Guidance for Good Practice.

RCN (2019) Restrictive physical intervention and therapeutic holding for children and young people: Guidance for nursing staff. Available at https://www.rcn.org.uk/professional-development/publications/pub-007746  Department of Health (2009) Reference Guide to consent for examination or treatment.
www.justice.gov.uk/protecting-thevulnerable/mental-capacity-act.
